title: Prince Harry, Duchess Meghan speak out about 'challenging' media backlash in TV interview
text:
Prince Harry and Duchess Meghan of Sussex, who are suing British tabloids for alleged "relentless" mistreatment, addressed their struggles and the toxic effect on the American former actress and new mom in a TV interview to air next week.

"Especially as a woman it's really – it's a lot. So you add this on top of just trying to be a new mom and trying to be a newlywed," Meghan told Britain's ITV anchor Tom Bradby in a documentary film, "Harry & Meghan: An African Journey," about their recently concluded 10-day tour of southern Africa.

Meghan, 38, talked for the first time in public about what it's been like coping with a fierce and often critical media spotlight since she and Harry, 35, got engaged in November 2017, married in May 2018 and gave birth to baby Archie Harrison Mountbatten-Windsor on May 6.

"And also thank you for asking, because not many people will have asked if I'm OK," Meghan told Bradby. "But it's a very real thing to be going through behind the scenes."

The ITV film of the Duke and Duchess of Sussex's tour of southern Africa with Archie will air Sunday in the United Kingdom and on Wednesday in the U.S. on ABC (10 p.m. E.T.), which picked up the project and is promoting it with excerpts and press releases.

Bradby is a familiar journalist to the young royals: He did the first interview with Prince William and the former Kate Middleton after they announced their engagement in 2010.

According to ABC, Bradby asked Meghan about whether it's been a "struggle" to adjust to life in the public eye as a new royal. Meghan quickly answered "yes," and added that it's especially difficult to handle the pressure while pregnant and as a new mom.

Prince Harry, Duchess Meghan of Sussex and their baby, Archie, in Cape Town, South Africa, on Sept. 25, 2019. (Photo: TOBY MELVILLE / POOL, EPA-EFE)

The couple have been adamant about their privacy since she became pregnant with Archie, who is seventh in line to the throne and Queen Elizabeth II's eighth great-grandchild.

They faced media criticism for keeping some information secret about Archie's birth such as where he was born (in a London hospital, as revealed in official birth registry documents weeks later).

They also declined to release the usual details – such as the identities of his godparents – about his christening a few months later.

"Look, any woman, especially when they're pregnant, you're really vulnerable," Meghan said. "And so that was made really challenging, and then, when you have a newborn, you know?"

ITV posted a tweet with a clip of video from the interview of Meghan talking about how the intense media spotlight has left her struggling to cope.

"Not many people have asked if I’m ok ... it’s a very real thing to be going through behind the scenes."



Meghan reveals to ITV's @tombradby the intense media spotlight has left her struggling to cope while becoming a mum #HarryAndMeghanhttps://t.co/Uy21iE6ozJpic.twitter.com/kZqhZV66OL — ITV News (@itvnews) October 18, 2019

Also in the interview, Harry was candid with Bradby about the continuing impact of the death of his mother, Princess Diana, in a 1997 Paris car crash while being pursued by paparazzi. Is he now at peace? Harry said her death is still a "wound that festers."

"I think (of) being part of this family, in this role, in this job every single time I see a camera, every single time I hear a click, every single time I see a flash," Harry said. "It takes me straight back, so in that respect it’s the worst reminder of her life as opposed to the best."

Meghan and Harry spoke to Bradby earlier in the Africa tour. On Oct. 1, the eve of the final day of the tour, news broke that the couple had filed separate lawsuits in the U.K. against three tabloids and their parent companies for alleged copyright infringement, invasion of privacy and phone hacking.

For their first engagement together after their Africa trip, Prince Harry and Duchess Meghan of Sussex attended the annual WellChild Awards in London on Oct.15, 2019. (Photo: TOBY MELVILLE/ POOL/AFP via Getty Images)

The news, which somewhat overshadowed the overall success of the tour, was accompanied by a passionate statement by Harry announcing Meghan's lawsuit and describing her as a victim of "relentless" and "malicious" coverage by the British tabloid press.

"Though this action may not be the safe one, it is the right one," Harry's statement said. "Because my deepest fear is history repeating itself. I've seen what happens when someone I love is commoditized to the point that they are no longer treated or seen as a real person. I lost my mother and now I watch my wife falling victim to the same powerful forces."

Harry's lawsuit against The Sun and The Daily Mirror alleges illegal hacking of his phone voicemail, recently discovered but dating back years.

Meghan's lawsuit is aimed at the Mail on Sunday, which published in February an anguished letter she wrote to her estranged father, Thomas Markle, after he missed the wedding. Her suit argues that this is a violation of copyright law, which holds that the contents of a private letter belong to the writer, not to the recipient.
